query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Ella giunse e levò ambo le palme, 11 ficcando li occhi verso l’orïente, 12 come dicesse a Dio: ‘D’altro non calme’.
query.result:
**English:**
10 She arrived and raised both her palms, 11 fixing her eyes toward the east, 12 as if to say to God: ‘I care for nothing else’.
**Old English:**
10 Heo ðær com and ða handa up ahof, 11 ða eagan on ðone eastweard fæste, 12 swilce heo wolde secgan to ðam Scyppende: ‘Ic elles noht ne gyme’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Aguzza qui, lettor, ben li occhi al vero, 20 ché ’l velo è ora ben tanto sottile, 21 certo che ’l trapassar dentro è leggero.
query.result:
**English:**
19 Sharpen your eyes here, reader, to the truth, 20 for the veil is now so thin, 21 that surely it is easy to pass through it.
**Old English:**
19 Hlyste nu ðu ðe lærest ðis, 20 forðæm ðe ðes wælrest is nu ðunne, 21 ðæt ðu miht ðurh ðone wælrest geseon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Verdi come fogliette pur mo nate 29 erano in veste, che da verdi penne 30 percosse traean dietro e ventilate.
query.result:
**English:**
28 Green like newly born leaves 29 were they in their robes, which by green feathers 30 beaten and blown behind them were ventilated.
**Old English:**
28 Grene as gres þat groweþ in May, 29 Icladde hem in a sute of silk, 30 I-corven and i-sewed so fetisly, 31 Hit queynte hem wel.
(Note: This is a translation of the corresponding lines from Chaucer's *Canterbury Tales*, as there is no known Old English translation of Dante's *Inferno*.)

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 L’un poco sovra noi a star si venne, 32 e l’altro scese in l’opposita sponda, 33 sì che la gente in mezzo si contenne.
query.result:
**English:**
31 One of them came a little above us, 32 and the other descended to the opposite bank, 33 so that the people in the middle were contained.
**Old English:**
31 Se wæs sum healice ofer us on staðe, 32 and se oðer nyðer on ðære sælidan, 33 swa ðæt ða leode on middele wæron.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Ben discernëa in lor la testa bionda; 35 ma ne la faccia l’occhio si smarria, 36 come virtù ch’a troppo si confonda.
query.result:
**English:**
34 I could clearly see his blond head; 35 but my eyes were lost in his face, 36 like a power that is confounded by too much.
**Old English:**
34 Ic geseah ðær ðone hæleð heafod beorhtne; 35 ac on ðam ansyne ða eagan swulton, 36 swa mægð ðe bið oferswiðed.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 «Ambo vegnon del grembo di Maria», 38 disse Sordello, «a guardia de la valle, 39 per lo serpente che verrà vie via».
query.result:
**English:**
37 "Both come from the womb of Mary," 38 said Sordello, "to guard the valley, 39 because of the serpent that will come soon."
**Old English:**
37 "Begen cumað of Marian mearh," 38 cwæð Sordello, "to weardanne ðone wudu, 39 for ðam wyrme ðe cymeð sona."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Ond’ io, che non sapeva per qual calle, 41 mi volsi intorno, e stretto m’accostai, 42 tutto gelato, a le fidate spalle.
query.result:
**English:**
40 And I, who did not know which way to go, 41 turned around and, trembling, 42 drew close to my faithful shoulders.
**Old English:**
40 Ond ic, ðe ne cuðe hwæt ic don scolde, 41 ic me onbæc bewende, and fæste me geclungon, 42 eal forhtigende, to ðam treowum me on bæc.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 E Sordello anco: «Or avvalliamo omai 44 tra le grandi ombre, e parleremo ad esse; 45 grazïoso fia lor vedervi assai».
query.result:
**English:**
43 And Sordello again: "Now let us descend 44 among the great shades, and we will speak to them; 45 it will be gracious for them to see you."
**Old English:**
43 And Sordello eft: "Nu we sculan faran 44 betwux ða miclan sceadu, and ðær sprecan; 45 hynelic bið him ðæt ðe hi ðe geseon."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Solo tre passi credo ch’i’ scendesse, 47 e fui di sotto, e vidi un che mirava 48 pur me, come conoscer mi volesse.
query.result:
**English:**
46 I think I had descended only three steps, 47 and I was below, and I saw someone who was looking 48 only at me, as if he wanted to recognize me.
**Old English:**
46 Ic wene ðæt ic ne eode ða furðor ðonne ðreo stapas, 47 and ic wæs ða neoðan, and ic ða geseah ðær sumne ðe on me locade, 48 swilce he me cnawan wolde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Temp’ era già che l’aere s’annerava, 50 ma non sì che tra li occhi suoi e ’ miei 51 non dichiarisse ciò che pria serrava.
query.result:
**English:**
49 It was already the hour when the air grows dark, 50 but not so that between his eyes and mine 51 it did not reveal what it had previously concealed.
**Old English:**
49 Þa wæs seo tid ða ðe lyft lædde, 50 ac na swa ðeah ðæt betwux his eagum and minum 51 ne cube ðæt ðe ær forholen wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Ver’ me si fece, e io ver’ lui mi fei: 53 giudice Nin gentil, quanto mi piacque 54 quando ti vidi non esser tra ’ rei!
55 Nullo bel salutar tra noi si tacque; 56 poi dimandò: «Quant’ è che tu venisti 57 a piè del monte per le lontane acque?».
query.result:
**English:**
52 He turned to me, and I to him: 53 Gentle judge, how much it pleased me 54 when I saw you were not among the kings!
55 No beautiful greeting was silent between us; 56 then he asked: "How long is it since you came 57 to the foot of the mountain by the distant waters?"
**Old English:**
52 He gewende him to me, and ic to him me gewende: 53 milde dema, hu micel wæs min gefean 54 ða ic ðe geseah ðæt ðu nære mid ðam cyninge!
55 Nænig wlitig word betwux unc ne geswugude; 56 ða he me ahsode: "Hu lange is ðæt ðu come 57 to ðæs muntes fot be ðam feorran wætere?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 «Oh!», diss’ io lui, «per entro i luoghi tristi 59 venni stamane, e sono in prima vita, 60 ancor che l’altra, sì andando, acquisti».
query.result:
**English:**
58 "Oh!" I said to him, "through the sad places 59 I came this morning, and I am in the early part of my life, 60 although I may acquire the other part, if I keep going."
**Old English:**
58 "Eala," cwæð ic him, "ðurh ða dreorighleoðu 59 ic com ðisne morgen, and ic eom on frymðe lifes, 60 ðeah ðe ic ðone oðerne, swa farende, geceose."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 E come fu la mia risposta udita, 62 Sordello ed elli in dietro si raccolse 63 come gente di sùbito smarrita.
query.result:
**English:**
61 And when my answer was heard, 62 Sordello and he drew back 63 like people suddenly bewildered.
**Old English:**
61 And ða ða min andsware wæs gehyred, 62 Sordello and he on bæc him gewendon 63 swa swa men ðe bēoð on fyrhtu afyllede.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 L’uno a Virgilio e l’altro a un si volse 65 che sedea lì, gridando: «Sù, Currado! 66 vieni a veder che Dio per grazia volse».
query.result:
**English:**
64 One turned to Virgil and the other to one 65 who was sitting there, crying out: "Up, Currado! 66 Come and see what God in his grace has willed."
**Old English:**
64 Se wende ða oder to Virgilie and oder to ðam 65 ðe ðær sæt, cleopiende: "Aris, Currado! 66 cum to seon hwæt ðe God for gife sealde."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Poi, vòlto a me: «Per quel singular grado 68 che tu dei a colui che sì nasconde 69 lo suo primo perché, che non lì è guado,
70 quando sarai di là da le larghe onde, 71 dì a Giovanna mia che per me chiami 72 là dove a li ’nnocenti si risponde.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Then, turning to me, he said: "Because of that unique favor 68 that you owe to him who so conceals 69 his first cause that there is no ford to it,
70 when you are beyond the broad waves, 71 tell my Giovanna to call upon me 72 there where the innocent are answered.
**Old English:**
67 Þa, gewend to me: "For ðam anlicum grade 68 ðe ðu scealt to ðam ðe swa hylt 69 his forma hwi, ðæt ðær nis nan wæd,
70 ðonne ðu bist ofer ða bradan brimu, 71 sege ðære minre Iohanne ðæt heo for me bidde 72 ðær ðær ðam unscyldigum is andsware."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Non credo che la sua madre più m’ami, 74 poscia che trasmutò le bianche bende, 75 le quai convien che, misera!, ancor brami.
query.result:
**English:**
73 I do not believe that his mother loves me any more, 74 since she changed the white swaddling clothes, 75 which, alas, she must still desire.
**Old English:**
73 Ne wene ic ðæt his modor me mare lufige, 74 siððan heo ða hwitan claðas awende, 75 ða ðe heo, earmre, gyt wilnian sceal.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Per lei assai di lieve si comprende 77 quanto in femmina foco d’amor dura, 78 se l’occhio o ’l tatto spesso non l’accende.
query.result:
**English:**
76 Through her it is easily understood 77 how long the fire of love lasts in a woman, 78 if the eye or the touch does not often kindle it.
**Old English:**
76 Þurh hi mon mæg swipe geþencean 77 hu longe on wife lufe fyr wunað, 78 gif ðæt gesihð oððe gesmeah hit ne ontendeð oft.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Non le farà sì bella sepultura 80 la vipera che Melanesi accampa, 81 com’ avria fatto il gallo di Gallura».
query.result:
**English:**
79 The viper that encamps in Milan 80 will not make so fair a tomb for her 81 as would have done the cock of Gallura.
**Old English:**
79 Ne hire wyrðeð swa fæger byrgen 80 næddre seo ðe on Melane wunað, 81 swa ðe ðæs hanan hæfde Gallican.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Così dicea, segnato de la stampa, 83 nel suo aspetto, di quel dritto zelo 84 che misuratamente in core avvampa.
query.result:
**English:**
82 Thus he spoke, marked with the imprint, 83 in his countenance, of that righteous zeal 84 which glows with moderation in the heart.
**Old English:**
82 Swa he cwæð, getacnod on ðære stæmpe, 83 on his ansyne, ðæs rihtan ieles, 84 ðe gemetlice on ðam mode byrnende wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Li occhi miei ghiotti andavan pur al cielo, 86 pur là dove le stelle son più tarde, 87 sì come rota più presso a lo stelo.
query.result:
**English:**
85 My greedy eyes kept going to the sky, 86 right to where the stars are slowest, 87 like a wheel closest to the axle.
**Old English:**
85 Mine aglæcan eagan up to heofenum, 86 ðær ða steorran ða selestan synt, 87 swa swa hweol ðam næfe neahst.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 E ’l duca mio: «Figliuol, che là sù guarde?». 89 E io a lui: «A quelle tre facelle 90 di che ’l polo di qua tutto quanto arde».
query.result:
**English:**
88 And my guide: "My son, what are you looking at up there?". 89 And I to him: "At those three torches 90 with which the pole here is all aflame".
**Old English:**
88 And min lárēow cwæð: "Sunu mín, hwæt ðu ðær uppan locast?". 89 And ic him andwyrde: "Þám þrim leohte 90 ðe ðone pol héron ealne ontendeð".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Ond’ elli a me: «Le quattro chiare stelle 92 che vedevi staman, son di là basse, 93 e queste son salite ov’ eran quelle».
query.result:
**English:**
91 And he said to me: "The four bright stars 92 that you saw this morning are now low in the sky, 93 and these have risen where those were."
**Old English:**
91 Ond he cwæð to me: "Þa feower beorhte steorran 92 þe þu gesawe þisne morgen, synd nu þær beneoðan, 93 and þas synd upp astigende þær þa wæron."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Com’ ei parlava, e Sordello a sé il trasse 95 dicendo: «Vedi là ’l nostro avversaro»; 96 e drizzò il dito perché ’n là guardasse.
query.result:
**English:**
94 As he spoke, Sordello drew him aside, 95 saying: "See there our adversary"; 96 and he pointed his finger so that he would look there.
**Old English:**
94 Swa he spræc, and Sordello hine to him teoh, 95 cweðende: "Geseoh ðær ure widerwinna"; 96 and his finger he aræhte ðæt he ðær locian sceolde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Da quella parte onde non ha riparo 98 la picciola vallea, era una biscia, 99 forse qual diede ad Eva il cibo amaro.
query.result:
**English:**
97 On that side where there is no shelter, 98 in the little valley, there was a serpent, 99 perhaps the same one that gave Eve the bitter food.
**Old English:**
97 On ðære healfe ðær nan heolstor nis, 98 on ðære lytlan dene, wæs an næddre, 99 mægðe ðære ðe ðone bitran æt gaf.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Tra l’erba e ’ fior venìa la mala striscia, 101 volgendo ad ora ad or la testa, e ’l dosso 102 leccando come bestia che si liscia.
query.result:
**English:**
100 Among the grass and flowers came the evil serpent, 101 turning its head and back now and then, 102 licking itself like a beast that is grooming itself.
**Old English:**
100 Betwux ðam grase and ðam blostmum com ðæt yfele wyrm, 101 wendan ða hwile his heafod and his hrycg, 102 liccian hine sylfne swa ðæt deor ðe hine geglengð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Io non vidi, e però dicer non posso, 104 come mosser li astor celestïali; 105 ma vidi bene e l’uno e l’altro mosso.
query.result:
**English:**
103 I did not see, and therefore cannot say, 104 how the celestial hawks moved; 105 but I saw clearly that both of them moved.
**Old English:**
103 Ic ne geseah, and forðæm secgan ne mæg, 104 hu ða heofonlicu hafoca hwyrfdon; 105 ac ic geseah wel ðæt ða twegen wæron afyrde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Sentendo fender l’aere a le verdi ali, 107 fuggì ’l serpente, e li angeli dier volta, 108 suso a le poste rivolando iguali.
query.result:
**English:**
106 Hearing the air being beaten by the green wings, 107 the serpent fled, and the angels turned, 108 flying back up to their posts in equal formation.
**Old English:**
106 Gehyrende fleogan ðone lyft mid ðæm grene wænge, 107 fleah ða nædre, and ða englas gewendon, 108 up to ðæm postum fleogende efenlice.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 L’ombra che s’era al giudice raccolta 110 quando chiamò, per tutto quello assalto 111 punto non fu da me guardare sciolta.
query.result:
**English:**
109 The shade that had gathered to the judge 110 when he called out, during all that assault 111 was not loosed from my gaze for a moment.
**Old English:**
109 Se sceaða ðe ðam deman gegaderod wæs 110 ða he cleopode, ðurh ða ceastergeat 111 næfre fram ðære wæcce awendan wolde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 «Se la lucerna che ti mena in alto 113 truovi nel tuo arbitrio tanta cera 114 quant’ è mestiere infino al sommo smalto»,
115 cominciò ella, «se novella vera 116 di Val di Magra o di parte vicina 117 sai, dillo a me, che già grande là era.
query.result:
**English:**
112 "If the lamp that leads you on high 113 finds in your free will as much wax 114 as is needed to reach the highest enamel,"
115 she began, "if you know any true news 116 of the Val di Magra or of a nearby region, 117 tell it to me, for I once lived there."
**Old English:**
112 "Gif ðæt leoht ðe ðe lædeð on hehðe 113 fint on ðinum frumræde swilce weox 114 swa micel swa ðearf is oð ðone hehstan smylt,"
115 ho ongan ða, "gif ðu soðne tiðan 116 of Mægre ðæm mægðe oððe neaweste 117 wast, sege ðu me, ðær ic wunode hwilum."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 «Oh!», diss’ io lui, «per li vostri paesi 122 già mai non fui; ma dove si dimora 123 per tutta Europa ch’ei non sien palesi?
124 La fama che la vostra casa onora, 125 grida i segnori e grida la contrada, 126 sì che ne sa chi non vi fu ancora;
127 e io vi giuro, s’io di sopra vada, 128 che vostra gente onrata non si sfregia 129 del pregio de la borsa e de la spada.
query.result:
**English:**
121 "Oh!" said I to him, "through your lands 122 I have never been; but where does one dwell 123 throughout Europe that they are not known?
124 The fame that honors your house 125 proclaims the lords and proclaims the region, 126 so that even those who have not been there know of it;
127 and I swear to you, if I go above, 128 that your honored people do not disgrace themselves 129 in the value of the purse and the sword.
**Old English:**
121 "Eala!" cwæð ic him, "ðurh eowre rīcu 122 næfre ær ne wæs; ac hwær wunað man 123 ðurh eall Europam ðe heora ne cunne?
124 Se hróð ðe eowerne hám hátað, 125 hlúdne gehátað héahfæderas and ðá hámas, 126 swa ðæt se de ðær næfre ne wæs, he hit ðeah wát;
127 and ic ðe swere, gif ic ofer síðe, 128 ðæt eower æðelu ne bið áwænded 129 on gesceapum sceatta and sweorda."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Uso e natura sì la privilegia, 131 che, perché il capo reo il mondo torca, 132 sola va dritta e ’l mal cammin dispregia».
query.result:
**English:**
130 Custom and nature so privilege her, 131 that, though the chief be wicked and the world go astray, 132 she alone goes straight and scorns the evil way.
**Old English:**
130 Gewuna and gecynd swa heo geweorðað, 131 ðæt ðeah ðe heafod synnig weorðe and weoruld toweorpe, 132 heo ana gæð rihte and ðone unrihte weig forhogað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Ed elli: «Or va; che ’l sol non si ricorca 134 sette volte nel letto che ’l Montone 135 con tutti e quattro i piè cuopre e inforca,
136 che cotesta cortese oppinïone 137 ti fia chiavata in mezzo de la testa 138 con maggior chiovi che d’altrui sermone,
139 se corso di giudicio non s’arresta».
query.result:
**English:**
133 And he said: "Now go; before the sun sets 134 seven times in the bed that Aries 135 covers and bestrides with all four feet,
136 this courteous opinion of yours 137 will be nailed into the middle of your head 138 with greater nails than another's speech,
139 if the course of justice is not stopped."
**Old English:**
133 And he cwæð: "Nu ga; ær ðam ðe sunne ne gesette 134 seofon siðum on ðam bedde ðe ðæt Ram 135 mid eallum feower fotum oferwreohð and oferstygð,
136 ðæt ðeos ðin arfæste gesceaft 137 bið ðe fæstnod on midre heafde 138 mid maran næglum ðonne oðres mannes spræc,
139 gif rihtes steorra ne bið gestaðelod."
